div1.p: Kean corrects an error in a Post editorial stating that an American scientist found the yellow fever germ. Kean points out that Reed demonstrated that yellow fever was spread by a particular variety of mosquito. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to the Editor of the Post, July 25, 1928
div1.opener:
23 July, 1928.
THE ORGANISM OF YELLOW FEVER.
To the Editor of the Post
Sir:
div1.p:
Yellow Fever has been always a mysterious disease and it is
not surprising that your very judicious and timely Editorial in Monday's
Post entitled “Free of the Fever” had a technical error in it. The
second sentence begins “The sanitation of the Isthmus, due to the genius
of the American Scientist who segregated the yellow fever germ and the
labors of that great health engineer Dr. Gorgas etc.” The American
scientist referred to was presumably Dr. Walter Reed of the Army who,
in the words of President Elliott “ gave to man control over that
dreadful scourge yellow fever”. But Reed did this by demonstrating
that the unknown cause of yellow fever was spread from man to man by
a particular variety of mosquito now called Aedes Egypti. The germ
has never been discovered. The distinguished Japanese scientist
Dr. Hideyo Noguchi believed that he had discovered it and even
prepared a serum which he believed to be curative, but it is now recognized
that what he really got hold of was the organism of infectious jaundice,
a quite fatal disease which clinically closely resembles yellow fever,
although its cause and method of spread are entirely different. By
a tragic fate Noguchi has recently died on the west coast of Africa of
this very disease, yellow fever, which he had studied so long and of which
he believed himself to be the conqueror.
